characters: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF TOWN
IN THE DARKNESS OUTSIDE THE VILLAGE
IN THE ABANDONED PART OF THE BUILDING
FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROOM
AROUND THE BACK OF THE BUILDING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the best part of town and probably never was. A  place of seedy, anonymous brick flophouses shackled by ru fire escapes, lying on an alley unique only for its bad  drainage. It's here, in the dim, flinty light, that a fig enters. Wearing a long coat and, despite the night, sunglasses, h pauses on the slimy asphalt and gazes up the sides of the flophouses, to their yellowish windows and competing Mexi radio stations. One window, dark and quiet on the third f catches his gaze. There's a metal hand railing in the alley that the long-c figure effortlessly pops up onto. Sunglasses focused on t window, he lowers himself into a motionless crouch, a per on the railing with the ease of a crow. Or a gargoyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn is a muddled, limp thing that does nothing to improv the alley. The figure is still there, a motionless gargoy perched on the railing. Watching the window. The shadows shorten, the air grows warmer, and now there' movement behind the window. The sunglassed gargoyle drops down off the railing, jumps to the first rung of the fire escape, and begins climbing

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE THIRD FLOOR WINDOW
dialogues.text: Is a room as grim as we expect. Lumpy iron bed, sink that been pissed into one too many times, and SIMON; a man in tight sweater and dark sunglasses, busily emptying his po on the ruined dresser: loose change, a town paper's obitu column. Simon's sunglassed eyes look up suddenly, his body  stifffening. He whips around to face the window just as i EXPLODES into fragments. The gargoyle LEAPS into the room on the trail of glass. S spins and THROWS himself against the intruder. The two  STRUGGLE savagely across the room, SMASHING chairs. Simon manages a grip on the gargoyle's face and POUNDS th back of his skull against the wall. The gargoyle gets his locked fists up and SWINGS them like a war club, SMACKING Simon's face and SPRAWLING him backwards onto the bed. The two, across the room for each other, pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon's climbed to his feet, the two men in sunglasses no walking slow circles around each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've found it, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gargoyle drops his head and DRIVES himself into Simon who HAMMERS the gargoyle with his fists. Blood SMEARS. The gargoyle's gotten free a knife that he JAMS into Simo leg. Pressing home his advantage, the gargoyle SLAMS Simo up against the wall. He TEARS open Simon's shirt, digging his fingers into the chest, RIPPING the skin aside, the f plunging deep, CRACKING the sternum bone, pushing even  further, toward the blood gouged pumping beneath -- -- Simon PLOWS his knee up between the gargoyle's legs. O and over. Till the grip loosens and Simon SHOVES him to o side, using the momentum and drives to SWING the body aro and at the shattered window. The gargoyle SMACKS the fram and COLLAPSES, his head CRACKING on the sill and FORCING shard of glass through his neck. Simon moves to the window and brushes aside the gargoyle' sunglasses, revealing two totally empty eye sockets. Push his thumbs into them, Simon uses the leverage to lift the gargoyle off the sill and push his body out the window. The gargoyle bounces once on the fire escape, then spread eagles thirty feet to the asphalt. Somebody turns up their Mexican radio station. The gargoyle's a wreck. But he manages, slowly -- his shattered remains arguing e inch -- to climb first to his knees, then miserably to hi feet. A bent, splattered, hopeless thing that manages to  stumble three or four feet before being HIT by a freeway- speed firebird BOMBING down the alley. The impact PINS the gargoyle to the grill and RAMS him in a brick wall, CRUSHING a chest that BELCHES out a sickly, bruised heart like a wet rag against the firebird's  windshield.

dialogues.speaker: THREE FLOORS ABOVE
dialogues.text: Simon leans against his splintered window and looks down the pinned and very finished body of the gargoyle. His ow shirt and pants are a mess of torn blood and his breathin is difficult. Pain flashes across his forehead as he chec that his own sunglasses still sit snugly on the bridge of his nose. At the sound of a distant siren Simon turns and quickly  finishes packing his duffle bag. Stiffly pulling on an  oversize surplus army jacket that partly conceals the dam beneath, he picks up the bag and painfully shuffles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gargoyle, still pinned to the wall by the firebird. A FLASH bounces off his skin. Then another. He's being  photographed. Go wide and find him in the middle of a pol investigation. Bored blue uniforms, yellow barrier tape. usual. A plain jane sedan pulls up and deposits THOMAS DAGGET,  thirties, tweed coat and steel notebook. He smiles at a c of cops, ducks under the yellow barrier, and nods a greet to an older uniform sergeant, BURROWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up at sky) Thought those clouds this morning  spelled rain for sure, but it's turned  into a beautiful day, wouldn't you  say, Sergeant Burrows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas takes a deep, healthy breath. Burrows just stares him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned you about that cheerful  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm working on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eyes finally make their way to the gargoyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend here did a half-gainer with a  firebird tuck from the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jumper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless he decided not to bother  opening the window first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drugs? Alcohol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he wasn't exactly in a condition  to walk a chalk line when we got  here. You're welcome to try and smell  his breath if you like, that is if  you can find the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ghouls been by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On their way. Willie promises a white  paper tomorrow. Or Wednesday,  depending on his golf game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firebird driver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burrows nods in the direction of a very shook up young ma sitting on the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jiminez. Was taking a short cut  to his job at a packing plant on San  Pedro. First thing he remembers about  the deceased is several vital organs  bouncing off his windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you had him walk a chalk line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's straight. Shook up some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at gargoyle) Anything on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wallet, license, nothing. He is  missing one or two things, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at tangled  mess) Along with everything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've found everything else -- and  what fun that was, let me tell you --  but the eyes are still AWOL. Might  just be stuck in the radiator grill.  Little weird though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both popping out together like that.  Worth a page in my scrapbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burrows and Thomas coming up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the room registered under?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything interesting inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are, what an intelligent,  experienced detective like yourself  could possibly construe as signs of  a struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the room, which is, of course, totally trashed Thomas steps over the splintered furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally nobody saw or heard  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In such a fine establishment as this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas looks at the splashes of blood, overturned dresser a newspaper, the "Chimney Rock Republican"; one name in i obit section circled. Burrows sighs and checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ku San's on fourteenth is still open  for another hour. Whatd'ya say we  pull out the 'ol "SUICIDE" rubber  stamp and get some lunch. Rancid  chow mein and watered beer for under  three bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at floor) There's glass in the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That usually happens when you break  a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amongst the glass fragments at Thomas' feet is a pair of  dark sunglasses. He picks them up, taps them in his palm, and looks out the window down to the man with no eyes, pi between brick and chrome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Chimney Rock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arizona desert, I think. Which is  exactly where I'm going to be in two  years, three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And give up all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breaking my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun sinking beneath the horizon of a vast and undulat expanse of desert. Travel through the landscape as the sky purples and darke and silhouettes tall, finger-like spires of volcanic rock Hear the coyotes, the wind making its constant, probing  search. Before the night swallows it all whole, Come upon The Town. It used to be something. But that's long gone. Now, wrapp in the sucking blackness of a wilderness night, it's a sh of a place. Lights still burn in some of the windows but fool no one. The ghosts are the majority here. Biding their time. Wait for The Town to surrender and slip beneath the waves of t desert. The wind slinks over the hills, creeps down past boarded- storefronts, skeletal ocitillo, and the rusting hulks of  abandoned mining equipment. The corpse of a summer's kite twists slowly on a power line.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE EDGE OF TOWN
dialogues.text: From the inky oblivion of the road, comes a crunch of gra

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF TOWN
dialogues.text: Stands a large, nineteenth century brick schoolhouse. An  icon from a more prosperous past, its dark massiveness wa meant for scores of ruddy-faced miner's kids. Now it seem to be imploding, eating itself with creeping decay. On th night it is silent and dark but for a small glow in one c and the faint sound of children's voices in song. It is a hymn. An ancient, Latin one. The melancholy beaut of voices rising and falling in choir.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: Is a school auditorium. On the stage, dwarfed by it, are  twenty five students from first grade to high school, sin together as a choir. A young woman, KATHERINE, directs th acapella voices as the small group of parents, lonely in huge room, look on.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: The voices drift on the night, down the road, and lap aga the peeling facade of a storefront. A mortuary.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: The rooms are dark but for one. There, bathed in the  flickering light of a tall candle, lies the body of the o general we saw at the opening.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Of the mortuary has a locked handle that jiggles from out A small panes of glass beside it is BROKEN by a hand.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SCHOOL AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: Young voices struggle with the complicated hymn and its p of centuries. Faces white, Mexican, Navaho. Katherine gui them with soft hands. She smiles in pride. They smile bac Proud. Of her. Of themselves and the beauty coming from t mouths. One small, beautiful navaho girl, MARY, maybe eight, gets special smile of special friendship from Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: THE MORTUARY'S
dialogues.text: Front door now stands ajar in the darkness. Small shards glass glisten in the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Is the dead General. Even in the bleached ravages of age death, his face still holds a shadow of vigor and pride. It takes a moment in the weak flicker of the candle to re someone is there with him. Simon in his oversized surplus jacket. His arms are folded tightly across his middle, as in deep cold. But his gaunt face is moist with sweat and breath is shallow and uneven. He stares at the old man be sunglasses and takes slow, cautious steps forward into th amber glow. Holding out two blood-stained fingers, Simon touches the  General's forehead. A new strain crosses his perspiring f Concentration. Placing his right palm on the General's chin and the left his forehead, Simon CRACKS OPEN the dead man's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SCHOOL AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: The hymn is reaching its aching climax of medieval longin

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MORTUARY
dialogues.text: Simon leans down to the open mouth, and in a voice soft a deeply weary,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qui ex Patre Flioque procedit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, with the school choir distant and faint in the nigh the living man places his mouth over that of the dead man

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SCHOOL AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: It's coffee and cake now as parents proudly hug their chi and congratulate their young teacher. Even in this gloomy crumbling building it's a warm, small town moment.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Simon has left the mortuary and now limps with difficulty through the silent streets, leaning against shop walls fo support.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SCHOOL BUILDING
dialogues.text: Through the doors out steps the eight year old Navaho gir Mary. Alone, she stands on the stone stairs and looks out into the night with sensitive eyes. She concentrates. Kno Katherine follows her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey bright eyes, what's the deal  being out here all alone without a  coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl's eyes seem too serious for a child's. Too  perceptive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine looks out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stares a moment longer, then becomes a child again,  smiling and popping Katherine one on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pig out on all the cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there might be one, tiny, skinny  piece left, but you're gonna have to  race me for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary suddenly points past Katherine's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Katherine turns Mary dashes back into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little sneak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine chases after her.

dialogues.speaker: AT THAT MOMENT
dialogues.text: Simon comes limping up from the road. His breathing's bad now as he moves stiffly along the school's brick walls, c to an old, rusty back door he creaks open and slides thro

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: He climbs a littered and disused staircase, past broken b bottles and condom wrappers to a dark and creaky second f It's part of the school building long abandoned. Doors to classrooms lie half off their hinges, windows are broken, rats squeak between ancient desks stacked like funeral py Simon, his breath echoing in the cold darkness, shuffles  along the broken linoleum till he comes to a rectangle cu in the wall where a row of lockers used to be. He crawls  into the space and there, surrounded by rot, curls up on  himself and sucks his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas Dagget's eyes opening slowly. He sits up in his be runs a hand through his hair, and looks out with only med enthusiasm at the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas lights an offering candle and kneels for a brief,  silent prayer. He crosses himself, stands, and walks for door. Before leaving he glances back at the altar. A  questioning moment between two akward, estranged friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas sits at his desk half-heartily trying to make sens of the three dozen files piled there. Lt. Paul, his boss, leans against a wall nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just looking for my "SUICIDE"  rubber stamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about leaving you without a  partner. Everything's up in the air  till the commission settles their  manpower budget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. (his phone rings) Dagget... It's done already? (smiles) Must have rained over the golf course  this morning. I'll be right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A set of golf clubs rest forelornly in the corner. An  irritable looking coroner fumes behind his desk as Thomas enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Willie, sorry to hear about the  weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coroner just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I bother sitting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas obeys as the coroner spreads out a stack of white  sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you like me to start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we can skip the cause of  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. To begin with, your man  has no eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't stuck in the radiator grill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he never had any eyes. We checked  the sockets. There's no optic nerve,  muscle pores, loose viscus, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also did a toxicology on his blood:  High sodium, elevated selenium, no  floating cholesterol platelets, trace  ammonia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's actually pretty common --  for an aborted fetus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubs eyes) I should have listened to Burrows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also did a bone section. Wasn't  that much trouble since most of them  were sticking out of his chest anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When babies grow up their bones get  larger by adding calcium layers over  the interior haversham canals. Child  growth isn't uniform though, comes  in spurts that always leave growth  rings in the bone. Everybody has  them -- except your man. That would,  to a hasty observer, seem to indicate  he had never been a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you, a cautious and learned  observer, of course have an  explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even remotely. Want to hear the  last one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even remotely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a hermaphrodite. (Thomas stares at him) -- Has both male and female sex  organs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of the possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can be impotent and frigid  all at the same time -- they don't  normally work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas sighs and climbs to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd love to say thank you, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I also have a bonus prize for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coroner opens his desk and pulls out a small, ancient looking leather bound book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found this sealed in his coat lining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas turns it over in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty old one, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas runs his finger across the gold-leaf cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We checked it out inside. Thought  there might be a name or fingerprint  somewhere. All we found was a curled  page marking the fourteenth chapter  of St. John's Revelations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no fourteenth chapter to  Revelations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this is the teacher's edition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas opens the bible and there it is, in Latin, the  fourteenth chapter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I keep this awhile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Can you sit on all this a few days,  Willie? Not circulate the file? I  need some time before all the  questions start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh, are we breaking the rules again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what else is new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas at his desk, working under a lone gooseneck lamp.  He's translating the fourteenth chapter of St. John's  Revelations from Latin onto a slip of paper. Finished, he sets the ancient bible down, turns off the gooseneck, and leans back in his chair, alone in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, outside The Town, horizons are distant, faraway thi The sky overhead is streaked red and blue with barely mor as the screen door of a simple stucco house swings open.  It's Katherine, the teacher. Wearing levis and boots, she carries a saddle swung over one denim shoulder out to a c behind the house where a horse shuffles and whinnies  impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute, in a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine throws the saddle over the horse and cinches it down as the sun, still tucked behind pink and grey cliffs begins to heat up the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep and narrow, an idyllic canyon of compressed sandston walls smoothed, rounded and etched by centuries of wind. tiny creek flows past weak banks of scrub pine and pocked sycamore. A silent place a long way and a long time from  anything but the approach of galloping hooves. Katherine and her horse run full-out through the canyon, clack and splash of hooves echoing off steep, shadowed wa Horse and rider drive each other harder and harder, their hot breath brief clouds in the arch, thin desert air. Boulders shattered by winter cold and summer heat, deep w cut caves hiding scorpions, sidewinders, or a wary mounta lion all pass as in a blur; arrogant hawks and patient  buzzards, ruins of thousand year old Anasazi villages hig on the cliffs, their weather-beaten skulls, seen and unse staring out; everything is one smear of color and smell a Katherine gallops past them and up the cliff trail, out o the canyon, and onto the main plateau.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PLATEAU
dialogues.text: Katherine strokes her horse and feeds it a bag of carrots She pulls a thermos from the pack, sits down against some old man rocks, and with the coffee steaming in her hand,  greets the sun now cresting the Chuska Mountains. There's a rutted, silty dirt road nearby. An ancient, bat school bus rattles its way past and stops. The bus driver Navaho, JOHN, climbs down and rubbing the side of his hea painfully walks up to Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could save my life with some  coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out an empty cup Katherine fills. Sipping painfu he lays down beside her and pulls the brim of his basebal cap over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to hear about it. (peeks out hopefully) Or maybe you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just checking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is full of young school kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't they be getting to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impromptu field trip. I'm broadening  their minds. And sparing them the  sight of their beloved chauffeur  barfing his guts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine's horse snorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate horses. How was the canyon?  Honey-suckle out yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't see any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that canyon. I hate this this  whole plateau. Too many goddamn  ghosts. Leave it to them I say. San  Diego, that's where I'm going. Or  Oxnard. I like the sound of that. Ox- nard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh lord protect us, another romantic  pale face in love with the desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just got to give it a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try growing up here. (tries word out on  tongue) Ox-nard. (sticks out coffee  cup) Uno mas, see-boo-play. (she pours) Speaking of romantic pale faces, the  rumor mill is in high gear again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That funny looking guy from Window  Rock. The BIA lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (non-committal) Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Say it isn't so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes the coffee and climbs painfully to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No prob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a credit to the community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuffles back to the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right children, looks sharp!  This is a school day! And no talking  loud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus coughs alive and crawls forward. Katherine waves the faces behind glass, then settles back for a last mome of peace as silence lays again over the land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showered and changed into her teaching clothes, Katherine climbs into a rattling pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine drives to work, passing on the outskirts the cl copper mine, vast and abandoned. Down beyond the fading m street lies the great crumbling brick pile that is the sc Katherine parks her truck, grabs her leather bag, and wal in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine's lecturing her students. All twenty-five of th There's high school age sons of white ranchers, Navaho gi on the edge of puberty, tiny Mexican children. All being  taught together in one room. It's dinosaur day. Katherine has a large fossilized bone her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is "Camposaurus". Camposaurus  was a herbavore, which meant he only  ate plants. Camposaur stayed mostly  to himself and never bothered anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girls smile. They like Camposaurus. Katherine  holds up another bone fragment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a leg fragment that belongs  to the killer of the plateau,  Alosaurus. Alosaurus was a vicious  carnivore, which meant he'd eat  anything that moved, especially nice,  juicy Camposaurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little boys grin. They like Alosaurus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both these guys lived together right  here on the White Rock plateau eighty  million years ago, when this area  used to be on the banks of a huge,  shallow sea. Remember how we talked  about how sedimentation fossilizes  bones? That's also what made the  hills out behind our town and put  the copper in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot of good that did us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine lifts off the desk an ancient 1950s gieger coun and switches it on. It ticks softly when she points it at the dino bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's radioactive! Like Godzilla!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a tiny bit, Alex. Do you know  why? Uranium, that's the rock they  use in nuclear power plants --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bombs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bombs Alex, yes, is all through  these hills naturally. Millions of  years ago the dinosaurs here ate  plants and drank water which had  uranium in it that became concentrated  in their bones, which is exactly  how, with Mr. Geiger counter here,  we're going to find some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class CHEERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the brick schoolhouse tiny in the background, Kather class trudges its way up the barren, rocky hillside behin the town. The teenage rancher's kids try to make time wit the Mexican girls One of the little boys has gotten into shoving match with a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming between them) -- Hey. Come on. What's the deal,  Brian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl folds her arms defiantly. The boy is pissed,  embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She, she called me a "Dick Head".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Brian. You get one free  insult. Make it good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian concentrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... You're a... Cow Demon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Uh... Okay. Everybody satisfied? (looks at Brian) Cow Demon?

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE HILL
dialogues.text: Katherine's given the geiger counter to the little Navaho girl, Mary. Focusing grimly on the rock in front of her,  Mary guides the detector over the stones till suddenly it begins clicking softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got one! I got one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The high school kids come up and help dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy... Easy... Don't break it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost immediately, an eye socket appears in the dust. As the students carefully brush away the dust, Katherine  looks back across the crumbly path. A coyote has crept up onto a near ledge. It just stands there. Watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mostly empty at this time of day and the young man  sitting in the pew, staring at the altar, is alone. His n is GABRIEL and he wears jeans, a faded leather jacket, an dark sunglasses, even inside. His thin hair is slicked ba and there's an almost feminine quality about him. He sits there a moment longer, staring, then gets up and  leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alley from the beginning. Gabriel pulls his old,  convertible rambler to a stop and walks into the flophous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes upstairs to the landing, where the door to the r is covered with a strip of yellow tape: POLICE INVESTIGAT DO NOT ENTER. Gabriel pulls the tape aside and KICKS the door open.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: It's still the disaster we remember. Gabriel walks slowly through the room. He scratches up some blood, tastes it. There's spray-painted outlines where the police have remo certain items. Gabriel takes note of this, tastes the blo again, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lunch break. Most of the students sit in loose cliqu around the front of the building; eating, skipping rope,  picking fights.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: The recently unearthed skull sits on Katherine's desk. Fe up beside it, she leans back in her chair looking through dinosaur book. One of her students, a twelve year old boy finishes cleaning up the floor and stands beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all done with the cleaning, Miss  Henley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jason. I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at book over  her shoulder) Find out what it is, yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's either a 44 million year  old Strychtosaurus or that cow Mr.  Sorenson lost last winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy, still standing beside her, begins to look nervou Slowly, he lets his weight rest against Katherine's shoul She smiles good naturedly up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go eat your lunch, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy immediately stiffens and begins backing up, almos relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Miss Henley. Thanks. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine watches him leave, smiles again, and goes back the book.

dialogues.speaker: AROUND THE BACK OF THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: On the abandoned back stairs, a couple of Mexican boys si smoking cigarettes. They whistle and kid with the four yo girls that pass them going up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Is the abandoned, decayed part of the building. The four  girls know they're not supposed to be here and that's pro half the fun. They run through the crumbling halls, giggl and hiding from one another. Their cries, the smack of th shoes, echo off off the peeling halls. One of them is Mary, running down a hall, banging a stick with another girl. At a corner Mary peels off from her fr runs down a new hall, turns a corner, And comes on Simon. He's still curled where we last saw h in the wall niche where some lockers used to be. The two  stare at one another. Finally,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look so good, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Miss Henley know you're here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one does, Mary. Can we keep it  just our secret. For a little while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can hear her friends coming closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice meeting you, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary goes to leave, stops, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hungry? I could bring  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and runs down the hall. Simon grits his teeth, turns to the wall, and prepares himself for a long, long  day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old fifties two-level, Polynesian lamps and glitter st now faded and browinish with water stains. Gabriel, the y man with the sunglasses and leather jacket we last saw ki down the door at the flophouse, walks up the apartment's  stairs to the second level, knocks once, and opens the do

dialogues.speaker: THE APARTMENT INSIDE
dialogues.text: Hasn't been very well looked after lately. Either has the occupant. Sitting slumped in a kitchen chair, staring at floor, he peers through dully yellow eyes that barely see to register his visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee Jerry, you look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes lift to Gabriel, revealing a pale, bloodless fac eaten with dried sores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon, pal. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel drops into the chair across from Jerry and pushes aside with distaste the maggot-ridden plates of food pile on the table. He reaches his hand out to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sing-song, like to a  baby) Come here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel puts his hand under Jerry's chin and turns the fa side to side, examining the cracked, decaying skin and fi eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Still a little life left in  you. Barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel releases Jerry's chin and slouches down in the ch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I want you to do  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to... Why won't you let  me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, I will. Promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, intestinal looking amber fluid begins to pool out Jerry's pant leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need some new clothes, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tear wells in Jerry's decomposing face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw come on, don't start. You know  how I hate that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so tired. I'm so goddamn tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the profanity. -- Just one  more favor. Honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deep sigh) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to get something for me.  A few personal effects the cops ripped  off from the lovely Allenwood Arms  on Seventh Street. It'll be sitting  in their property room down on San  Julian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to just go in there?  Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give you a bath, put on some decent  clothes, (beat) Maybe a very large brim hat, you'll  be fine. Just go in between five and  five-ten, it's a shift change and  nobody'll notice you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cocks an eye) C'mon. (tosses yellow ID  card onto table) This should be more or less up to  date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a name this stuff is under?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Doe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't that surprise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel gets up, pats Jerry on the head, and walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you tonight. (flips him silver  dollar) Here's some bus fare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SLAM of a racquetball against the scarred white wall an indoor court. It ricochets off the ceiling, hits the b glass partition, and is SLAMMED again. Four players, incl Thomas, grunt and sweat across the hardwood floor. It's  brutal. Shoulders and knees bang off one another. One of the players falls back, yells to Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cover me! Cover me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas dives into position to make the save, recovers, an yells to the player as he dashes to the next corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The player SLAMS it brutally at Thomas, who misses misera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another player picks up the dead ball and puts his arm ar Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're missing the point of the game,  Thomas. You must absolutely trust no  one. Form alliances, but break them.  Lure another to trust you, then betray  him! You play with too much honor.  Sink to the gutter. Use people. Lie  and double-cross them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Player #2 tosses the ball to Thomas, who serves, and the  scuffling is back on. Shouts to one another. Promises of  support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Thomas, let's take out Sam  together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas and Player #2 team up on a third player, pressing hard. Suddenly Thomas breaks back, intercepts the ball, a drives against Player #2. The about-face is too abrupt fo him and Player #2 is eliminated in a double-cross. He smi proudly at Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magnificent decadence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas and the three players congratulate each other on t evil and treachery in each other's strategies as they sho down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The important thing, Tom, is seeing  the game for what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sickening, hopeless, giant sucking  hole of depravity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Thomas combs his hair and slips on his regimental  detective's suit 'n tie, the other three put on their bla pants, shirts, and stiff white Roman collars. They're pri Two of the priests hoist their gym bags and head for the  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya guys next Tuesday, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas is left alone with Player (priest) #2, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Y'now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life on the dark side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Can I ask you about something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to stay between us. I need  your word on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a racquetball player or a priest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the priest for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a case. We found this guy. He  was... different. But he had on him  an old bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the bible out of a cloth sack and hands it to Bi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Vichini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worth a little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than a little. They're the best.  Sixth century. Hand illuminated.  Vichini only did twenty, each pocket  size for a king to carry into battle  beside his heart. Some consider them  the finest bibles ever made. I thought  they'd all be in museums. What are  you doing with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's a bit special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's has a bonus chapter to St, John's  Revelations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from slip of  paper) "And as in the first war, the angels  so fought over the nature of their  God, and there was much vanity and  destruction in heaven. For some angels  called their Lord the son of God,  and others called Him the begotten  father of Jesus Christ." What do you  think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never heard that quote before.  Theologically, The "first war"  obviously refers to the war in heaven  where Michael the archangel threw  out Satan and his gang. Old time  bible stuff. But this implies there  was a second war. That's news to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the rest of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a fairly common theological  debate. Or was. The idea that if  Christ is God's son, does that make  him less than God or are they the  same being in different forms. That  very argument almost tore the early  Christian church apart in the 4th  Century. That was the good old days  when people actually worried about  theology. Anyway, it was settled  when the bishops of the world got to  together at the Council of Nicene in  325 and hashed out the various  interpretations of scripture into a  uniform dogma of belief. The result  was the Nicene Creed, which basically  said that Christ was in fact the  same as God and was owed the same  power and respect as the Father.  That they were the same. (smiles) But it's not exactly the sort of  thing angels would fight over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they could just ask God, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it's possible that John  might have written that extra chapter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows? Vichini was the greatest  biblical scholar of the age, some  claimed he made his own translations  from the original writings. Maybe he  did find some unknown writings by  John. It's possible I suppose. John  always was a little negative about  angels. All this actually has  something to do with an LAPD murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. Maybe. Probably  not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to break it you, but that  particular family spat has been  settled for 1,600 years. Nobody loses  sleep over it anymore. Honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did John have against angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he didn't trust them much. All  that running around smiting and  killing in the name of the Lord.  God's wild bunch. He thought it made  them fickle and vain. One click above  ghosts. Satan didn't help the image  much either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he did start as an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas walks Bill out to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when are you going to get a real  job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean with the Church?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You almost did it once. I never saw  a seminary student more called to  the collar than you. Why didn't you  ever become ordained?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to tell it to me sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is squat and brick. A non-descrip warehouse  that subs as a police evidence storage area. The sun is hard today as it beats down on Jerry's large- brimmed felt hat. Daylight and Jerry don't get along very well. His sunken, filmy eyes squint at its glare. The dec flesh cracking along his cheeks flames at its touch. He  shuffles down the sidewalk, the brackish, amber fluid tha gurgles down his leg filling his shoes and leaving behind shiny wet footprints like a snail. There's nobody around the back door and its unlocked. Jer shrunken claws pull it open.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Is a crush of filing cabinets and erector-set shelves. Al of it crammed with low grade stuff. The heroin busts and  million dollar currency arrests don't end up here. Here i all shoe boxes and dusty files. Fragments of small lives  forgotten. Jerry pulls the brim of his hat down even further as he w his way past rack after rack. The single uniform he meets looks only casually at Jerry's lapel ID badge. It's on th third shelf he finds it. John Doe #78. Jerry lifts the bo and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel steps off the elevator and follows the signs for  MEDICAL EXAMINER. Along the way he passes a checkpoint gu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a pass, friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just be a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel walks back to the guard, smiles, and KNOCKS him c out of his chair with the back of his arm. The guard SMAC against the wall and crumples out of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiled floor and refrigerated corpses. Nobody's around whe Gabriel enters. He walks over to a file cabinet and remov a thick folder. Then he walks to the big filing cabinets, the ones that hold a body in each drawer. He strolls alon tapping each label till he finds the one he's looking for slides it open, and looks down at the naked body of the  gargoyle. He's been sewed back together. Kind of. Gabriel grabs the eyeless corpse under the armpits and drags him out onto t floor where he pushes the legs together and outstretches arms, like a crucifix. From his coat Gabriel takes out a  small vial of oil and rubs it onto the gargoyle's feet an hands. Anointing them. Then with the tip of his finger, h draws a faint sign of the cross on the forehead, stands, walks for the door. In the background, as Gabriel leaves, we see the body of gargoyle BURST into flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine's students are shuffling back from lunch to the seats, making small talk and paper airplanes. Katherine d a head count, then stops a young boy coming through the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, have you seen Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's out back somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to girl) Allison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't seen her since lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're you guys up in the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls, Mary's friends, shrug innocently. Katherine si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay everybody, get started on today's  reading. Quietly. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine closes the door behind her. The class immediate erupts into goofing off. The door opens again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean quiet.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ABANDONED PART OF THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: Katherine walks through decayed and rusting halls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's spooky up here. A part of the building Katherine cle dislikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary... (to herself) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine calls out Mary's name a few more times, turns a few more corners, and suddenly comes on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's sitting beside Simon, the bleeding, ashen-faced ma with sunglasses. She's giving Simon a piece of sandwich a a coke. Katherine is instantly wary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Simon and I were --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary reluctantly walks over to Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary frowns, waves once to Simon, and leaves. There's a  heaviness to the air around Simon. A kind of buzzing.  Katherine blinks her eyes a few times. Focuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't doing any harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not her I'm worried about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small job. Mostly done now. Just  passing through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is school property, you can't  sleep here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't part of the plan. Honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (notices blood stains) Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That buzz. Katherine rubs the side of her temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't, but I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I rather doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine turns and leaves, her footsteps fading. Mary ap again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. I thought you'd left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hid. I'm very clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you are. (beat) You were nice to give me the food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't much time, Mary. And since  you've been so nice to me, there's  something I'd very much like to give  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for a little while. Something  very special. Can you keep it a  secret? The biggest secret ever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a couple of shy steps toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she does --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine, outside the building, rounding up some of the  kids who decided to take an impromptu recess. Hustling th last one up the stairs, she pauses suddenly. She hears  something. Faint coughing. Katherine walks back around the side of the building and  sees Mary bent over, vomiting. Katherine rushes up to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, pumpkin? Did you  eat something? (concerned beat) Did he give you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary coughs up the last of her lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I go home now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine wipes off Mary's mouth with a hanky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, hon. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine drives Mary home, a dusty, tired mobile home sl among the saguaro and tumbleweed on the edge of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Katherine pull open the door and enter. Mary's  elderly grandmother is sitting watching "All My Children" She smiles at Katherine and looks at Mary with concern as the little girl rubs her stomach and explains something i Navaho.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Katherine helps tuck Mary in bed as her grandmother bring glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have the school send over a  doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandmother sits beside Mary, whispers gently in Nava and softly stokes her brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone) ...He's was just laying up there. I  thought, with the kids and  everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of my boys are up the highway  on a tanker spill at the moment.  They may be a while. These people  are rarely any problem. I'll have a  deputy come by tonight or tomorrow  and shoo him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looked hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all do, ma'am. Inside or out,  they're all damaged goods.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alone and tucked into bed, Mary stares off at something v very far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun orange and fading outside his window, Thomas drif off into a nap on his couch. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your friendly coroner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is my friendly coroner, after a  long day at work, calling me at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something you'll want to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you'll definitely want to see  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor is the smoldering, blackened outline of a bo A thick, slimy goo gurgles and pops. The whole room is af with acrid smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They also took the autopsy file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "They"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He, she, it. They took it. They also  lifted all the physical evidence  from the San Julian impound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop at the desk is in the hospital  as we speak with a broken collarbone.  Everyone else was down the hall  watching the basketball playoffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who won?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Foul on the buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas jams his hands in his pockets and leans against an autopsy table. Watches the smoke curl slowly up from the  impossibly melted goo in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like the snow angels we used  to make as kids. Lie down in a clean  bank. Move your arms up and down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this means. Our friend's  cleaned out all the evidence on this  guy. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the cop get a look at who nailed  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall. Smiled a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wore sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas pulls out out his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna figure this one out, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you do, give me a call. Tell me  I'm not crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel crouches on the linoleum and pours everything out the evidence box onto the floor. He sifts through it, a s appearing when comes across the Chimney Rock Republican a its circled obituary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the desert, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry is looking worse by the day. A rotting, oozing fiss has opened on his forehead. His right eye doesn't move  anymore. He sits on a kitchen chair glumly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised. You promised that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Soon. Honest. Don't be a pest  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Never trust a fucking angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas sits hunched over his notes from the first day of investigation. Written in it is the Chimney Rock Republic and the obituary name of General Arnold Hawthorn. Lt. Pau sits down in the chair opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever have one of those  afternoons where you feel no one's  giving you a straight answer about  anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, maybe five or six times a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading sheet) It says here somebody got into the  property warehouse and cleaned  everything out of your evidence box.  No, he did leave one thing. A  footprint. 11-D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mud on his shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spinal fluid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas slowly closes his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to get a straight answer  out of you either, am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lt. rubs his eyes tiredly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to go to Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your health?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I can give you a straight answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, why not? Take the kids. See  the Grand Canyon. Send me a fucking  postcard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a headache, Tom, and I hate  my life. If you have to go, go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On an utterly lonely blacktop, Gabriel shoots by in his t down rambler, insignificant in the night's vastness. Jerr in the back, feet up on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you need me? I can hardly  walk now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some things are human work, son.  Live or dead, human work. Besides, I  like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky moi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel suddenly stands on the brakes, SCREECHING the ram to a dusty stop. He kills the engine and everything is  instantly whispering night and coyote howls. Gabriel clim out and walks to the edge of a cliff. Far below, nestled  among the finger-like spires of volcanic cones, lies The  Town. Twinkling lights in a cold, dark embrace. Gabriel pushes his sunglasses up his nose and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can always smell a graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two coyotes begin fighting and snarling with each other i the dust nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a low hill at the edge of town. Cracked, sinking  headstones. The rambler's parked next to a new one, Slim  Pickens on the AM, as Jerry digs up the fresh grave marke General Arnold Hawthorne. Gabriel sits perched on the  headstone over the grave like a winged creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're enjoying this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always enjoy watching you work,  Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I ever get you in my life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you didn't really want to  kill yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I did it, didn't I? I did kill  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes. Technically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're just keeping me alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letting you die slower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so in your debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jerry. I'm touched. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's shovel CLANKS onto something hard. He scrapes awa the dirt, revealing a coffin lid. With a socket wrench Je removes the fastening bolts, then with the edge of his sh pries open the lid. It's the ancient, wasted general we saw at the beginning. His medals flash in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much to look at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but it's not what's on the outside  that matters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel leaps off his perch down into the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- It's what's on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel reaches down, places one hand on the General's  forehead, one on his chin, and BREAKS the mouth open. He  gazes down into it. Then suddenly stiffens and straighten up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset) It's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel frantically look in the ears. Up the nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh, bad news for the war effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spins wildly on him) Shut up!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel BANGS the coffin lid in frustration. Tries to thi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, if you were a soul, where would  you hide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell away from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The numbers on the clock radio roll over five AM and the  news comes on. Thomas stirs in bed, rubs his eyes, and lo out at a sky untouched by any sign of dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In coat and tie, Thomas sits in his spartan kitchen stirr a coffee when the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey little brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Hey. How's the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's the usual. Except for a  guppy. the world's minus one guppy  this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jamie and Mac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep asking for Uncle Tommy.  The only man that can make stuffed  bears talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My one true calling. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's five-thirty in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I just thought I should call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always were telepathic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas looks up at his overnight bag, sitting half-packed the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my job, Jan. I go places  sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had this terrible feeling  about it. What's happening, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss you. Even when you're here. I  miss you. I miss my brother. It's  been four years, Tom, since...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the only blood family we have  left, you and me. I worry about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about the dawn-attack call. I  love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too, Jan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cradles the phone, stares at it, then picks up his  overnight bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent and dead at this hour. Gabriel's boots creak on th floorboards of the 19th century plank sidewalks. He taps finger aimlessly along plate glass shop windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, what a dump, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, limping on a foot that's caving in on itself, wipi the spinal fluid out of his dead eye, shuffles along behi Gabriel pops off the elevated sidewalk, grabs a parking m and swings himself playfully around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't this shit ever go down in  Miami? Or Bora Bora? I feel like  I've spent my whole damn stay in gin  swills like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life's a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel suddenly freezes. He sticks his nose up, sniffs l a coyote, then abruptly drops to the ground in a push-up smells the dirt. Tastes it with his tongue. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fracture of broken moon tumbles through shattered windo and falls dully across shapes old, shapes forgotten, and shape trying hopelessly to drag itself across the floor.  It's Simon; breath a rasp, blood-soaked pants leaving a l smear behind him like a hemorrhaging snail. He coughs, dr an arm across the lenses of his sunglasses, And looks up at a pair of black, lizard-skin boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon rolls on his back and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks up at puss-faced Jerry, leaning quietly in a  dark corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind me. Just along for the  ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel sits down against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what shall we talk about?  Theology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little talked out on theology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel turns his boot to the moon, watches the pale ligh glint back off the lizard scales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't happen to have it on you by  chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would have been too easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon suddenly JUMPS to his feet. Tries to escape. Jerry  trips him, SPRAWLING Simon back to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Simon. Get serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel walks over to him. Puts his face close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. Where's the soul? (beat) You know. So high. Used to reside in  the recently departed General  Hawthorne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon doesn't answer. Gabriel shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have it your way, big guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do have one question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even remember what this war's  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel pauses, almost thoughtfully. Then he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's hardly the point, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I never did get the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do it, Gabriel? How do  you go on and on in this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it here, Simon. I always have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so tired...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel grasps Simon's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then join us, Simon. Reject the Nicene  Council. We were here first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it, Gabriel. I don't even  know why anymore, but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swallows hard) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel's hand is suddenly on Simon's face, fingers sprea claw-like. They press into the flesh. Hard. And harder. U Simon starts to bleed. Then to burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine startles abruptly in her bed at the faraway sou of Simon's screams. Screams carried either on the wind or her dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asleep, sweaty, shivering, Mary suddenly opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel releases his grip on Simon, letting him fall back against the wall, afire. His clothes twist and blacken. H skin creeps and pops. His sunglasses melt and fall away;  revealing two hollow pits beneath. Gabriel lifts Simon's  entire body up off the floor by just the disintegrating f and stares into the hollow pits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the fires go out. Gabriel drops the crackling, acrid  body onto the floor. Impossibly, through the sizzling muc and molten hair, it breathes. It gasps in pain. It won't  die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do this for five months,  Simon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skies above lighten and smear blue and red.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Finishes dressing for school, picks up her teaching bag, crunches out across the gravel to her pick-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel's lizard boots pace back and forth past Simon's  writhing, burning body. Gabriel's more jittery now. Losin his patience. He bends down and pulls Simon's face up to  his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is getting boring, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it? Where did you put it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seared skin around Simon's mouth comes off in Gabriel hand. But Simon is still, even now, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flings Simon with a horrible crunch against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just about out of tricks here.  You're a tough one, friend. Old  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over and places a hand with something like frien on Simon's charred shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God loves you, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with the other hand Gabriel JAMS his fist into Simon' chest, PULLING OUT a lumpy, burned heart. Simon's mouth  springs open and hisses emptily. Gabriel slips the heart  into his pocket and lets go of Simon's shoulder. The body instantly disintegrates and crashes to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine squints at the morning glare as she drives thro town. Pulling into the school's drive she sees, parked at the building's back door, a sheriff's patrol car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine comes up the stairs of the building's abandoned floor, passing the stacks of rotting desks toward where s last saw Simon. There's a bad smell in the air. At a turn stands a deputy that looks up as Katherine  approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may want to skip this, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine looks past him to where a second deputy crouche down beside... beside something. It's human shaped, but l a shadow. A shadow twisted in agony and slicked with a ta smoldering ooze. The smell is overpowering. The crouched  deputy has a handkerchief over his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Katherine) Were any of your students up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine pulls-up and parks.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Mary is still in bed, droopy-eyed and sweating. Her  grandmother is there, and so is an elderly Navaho. He sta beside Mary's side, holding above her body a clenched pou that he passes slowly back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to grandmother) How is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the doctor come by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He found nothing. But something is  in her. I know. Something the  Belagaana doctor can't see. The night  people have been around two days  now. It is a warning. (nods to Navaho man) So we have called the hand trembler.  To find if she must have an Enemy  Ghost Way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man mumbles a soft chant as he moves the pouch ba and forth across Mary's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine walks back out toward her pickup. She stops. Th yards away, almost invisible in the sage say for the glar of its evil, intelligent eyes, is a coyote. As she feels  it's gaze a shadow suddenly crosses her shoulder. Katheri turns quickly but only barely catches, out of the corner her eye, a glimpse of something very large. And winged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge semi ROARING deafeningly past on an empty desert  highway, KICKING UP a dusty cyclone that drifts over a on horse gas station and Thomas, sitting there in his car  checking a map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small townish; old adobe and stucco walls, cannon on the  front lawn, every door loudly declaring itself a departme SOCIAL SERVICES, COURTS, and, SHERIFF.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
