dialogues.text: The Sheriff's personal office is turn of the century rega with high beam ceilings and rotating fans. Nothing seems  newer than 1940, including the coffee pot the Sheriff pou a mugful from. Trim with glasses, bolo tie and boots, he  looks like Barry Goldwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to what do I owe the thrill of a  visit from a So Cal homicide cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the coffee to Thomas, sitting in a chair beside solid oak desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run of of the mill psycho killer  body dismemberment on our end. The  usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely place, Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a lead I wanted to run down  Chimney Rock way. Thought I'd do the  courtesy of telling you first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome to put a babysitter  on me if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, this is the third biggest county  in the country, not even counting  the 25,000 square mile Indian  reservation right next door, and  I've got fewer men than just one of  your little palm tree precincts to  cover all of it. 'Fraid the only  help you're gonna get from me, short  of another shoot out at the OK Corral,  is that cup of coffee in your hand.  A middle-aged secretary enters with  a stack of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the last week's watch reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands them to the Sheriff, who passes them on to Thom He flips through the stack, comes up with nothing. The  secretary hands another, single sheet to the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby just called this in from Chimney  Rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas perks at The Town's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Thomas) Sent a car up there this morning.  Teacher complained some vagrant was  sleeping in her schoolhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff's brow crinkles in consternation as he reads  further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to secretary) Damn it, get Bobby on the phone,  Clarice. What the hell is this suppose  to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re report) May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff hands it to him. Glancing at it we pick up wo like BURNED, BLACK SLICK, BODY OUTLINE. Thomas copies the name of the school down, gulps his coffee, and shakes the Sheriff's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Thomas turns to  leave) Small piece of advice, Lt. Dagget,  that I give free of charge to all  visiting big city policemen: It's  wild country up there. Always has  been, always will be. You come across  anything that snarls, you call me  first, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never turn down advice, Sheriff.  Especially when it's free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas's sedan passing through the vast, empty land.

dialogues.speaker: FAR ON THE HORIZON
dialogues.text: A small clump of buildings emerge clinging hopelessly to earth. The Town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A former miner's hotel, stone walls and sagging wrought i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas tosses his bag onto the bed, opens the balcony doo and looks out on the crumbly shale hills, the abandoned  prospecting shacks, and the Chuska Mountains, clouds brew darkly across its shattered back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A close-up of the circled newspaper obituary for General  Hawthorne. The paper lowers and reveals behind it the  general's grave. The dirt around the tomb is loose, recen filled. The grave keeper, a young, gangly, drifter type s nearby with his shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long ago was he buried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody dug him up last night. I  just finished putting him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they take anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas's breath escapes in warm clouds here in the unheat abandoned part of the building. Rats scurry away from fee on the dark, human-like stain on the floor as Thomas crou down beside it. He probes the dried, black, crusty flotsa with his ball-point pen. Just like the burned body back a the morgue. Far away you can hear the sounds of children. Of a teache voice.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS
dialogues.text: It's only past the final door, into the smallest corner o the building, that the walls become clean and brightly pa by eager third graders. The creepy silence transforms its into the giggles of children as they bang open the classr door and whoop themselves outside for recess. The last one out is Katherine. She's surprised to see Tho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Can I help you with something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Dagget. I'm with the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the guy upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to ask you a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've kinda got my hands full right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just tag along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine unlocks a hall cabinet and pulls out a stack of volleyballs. She tosses two to Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, make yourself useful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arms full, she pushes the building door open with her sho and backs out into the sunshine. She tosses the balls out the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, everbody stays on the courts  today. (kids groan) -- I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down beside Thomas on the building's stone steps

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What grade is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Town doesn't look that small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly all ghosts now. When the copper  mine closed it took most of the town  with it. We just teach out of this  one corner of the schoolhouse now.  Rest of it's been abandoned for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Just me. (to kid threatening  another) -- Randy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it again and I'll put your head  in the door and slam it. (to Thomas) Love and understanding are important  tools in education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children skitter back and forth playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man upstairs, did you talk to  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to know what the hell he  was doing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it wasn't part of the plan. He  looked hurt. Bloody. Like someone  had cut him. That happens here. (beat) Was that... stuff... on the floor  really him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did any of the children talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protective) She's home sick from school today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I speak with her parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dead. She lives with her  grandmother. I'll have to ask her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. (stands, hands her  slip of paper) This is my number at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas starts away. Pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know Arnold Hawthorne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General? Saw him here and there.  It's a small town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Military man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a million years ago. His  interests lately were more like  gardening and herbal tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you go to the funeral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone did. He lived here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dark hidden secrets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no secrets in small towns,  Mr. Dagget, dark or otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: Up the crumbly embankment, sitting perched on the roof of abandoned house, is Gabriel. He watches Thomas walk to hi car. He watches the children playing, lifting his nose to snort the air, like a coyote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas sifts through some clippings on General Hawthrone. Tactical genius. The man who saved Korea. Brutal. Almost  court marshalled a dozen times for his inspired savagery. truly ruthless man -- who spent the last twenty years qui tending his garden in a dying town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, simple, and woodplanked. The church we saw at the  beginning. Thomas sits there, staring at the candles, the altar, the crucifix. He's alone there. But for a creeping buzz. A feeling in t air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's unusual to see someone of your  age in church on a weekday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas turns in surprise. Gabriel is kneeling in the row  behind, inches from his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get me wrong. I think it's an  excellent sign of character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something cold and creepy about Gabriel. Out of p in here. There's another sound. Teeth chattering far in t back. Thomas turns and sees Jerry, deep in the shadows of the choir box. Jerry waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind him. He shouldn't even be  in here. Least not standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those sunglasses. Impenetrably dark. Like at the skid row flophouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you found it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. Have you found what you're  looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appraising him) I don't doubt it. (stands) You'll let me know? When you find  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he walks out, leaving Thomas alone in a place gone  suddenly cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a note waiting for him at the front desk: "Her na is Mary Tsosie. You can talk to her at noon tomorrow. I'l be at the VFW hall tonight -- Katherine."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas sticks his head in through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an Indian bingo game. Thomas' eyes drift down the ta packed with elderly faces and find Katherine and John the Navaho bus driver. Katherine waves him over. Both her and John are totally obsessed with the game, keeping track of several cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got your note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat. You need a card. Here,  play one of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay. Really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must learn to shed your high- strung ways, pale face. You must  learn the spirit joy in patience,  peace, and making fifty or sixty  bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, this is Mr. Dagget. Says he's  with the police, though judging by  his coat and basic command of the  english language, I don't think it's  from anywhere around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes John's hand) Tom. From Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That near Oxnard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long way from home, Tom-from-Los- Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas lazily glances at his card, his eyes opening sudde wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Hey, wait. I won. I won!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- What? No way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recount! Recount!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Navaho social in full swing -- square dancing. The Indi band on stage plays deeply traditional, inspiring, -- Han Williams. John easily whirls Katherine around; a steely-e master square dancer. Thomas leans against the wall tuggi on a beer. When John releases her for another partner she points at Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, don't be a drip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him out onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very good at this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they dance) No, you're not, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. Gets a smile out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couples drift off the building's porch and into the stree to cool off, smoke, and take a few hits off paper bags. J leans against the brick wall, tugs liberally from his pap bag, and exchanges war hoops with some friends across the street. He passes the bag to Katherine and Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's our star pupil feeling today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary? The school doctor came by.  Declared it "Non-specific  gastrointestinal disorder".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latin for "I don't have the slightest  fucking idea".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she be able to talk with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's up to her. (to John) Mary's grandmother called a hand  trembler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh oh. Hocus pocus time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends what the hand trembler says.  People call them in when they think  a witch or a Yei is trying to sprinkle  corpse sickness in their hogan, or  if the Night People have been hanging  around too much. Night people screw  around a lot, but they're good at  warning of evil ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are the Night People?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come as coyotes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas sits in the truck's bed as they Katherine drives  through town. John, on the near side of royally toasted, his boot stuck out the passenger window. Thomas looks up the night sky. At its blaze of stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful stars out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John drinks again from his bottle, rests his head on the  open window and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much fucking sky in the desert.  It pushes on you. (sighs) Sometimes I wonder if anyone in heaven  even knows this place is here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early American bachelor. John collapses onto the couch as Katherine heads for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you keep the coffee in this  joint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She messes with the grounds and filter. Thomas paces the  room, looks over the pictures and a few weavings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens if the hand trembler  says a ghost has been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Messing with Mary? If you're smart  you say thank you very much and forget  about it. But if you're heavy  traditional, and Mary's people are  serious traditional, you have an  Enemy Ghost Way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn expensive. It's a Sing to  purify and drive off the corpse  sickness. Two days of dancing and  ceremony and feeding the whole damn  village. Not even to mention hiring  the yataallii, if you can even find  one these days. And you can bet they  don't come cheap. But every clan  does it a bit different. Especially  Mary's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bitter Sky Clan. Hard core  reservation. No lights, no running  water, no HBO. Their village is out  on the edge of Old Woman Butte.  Million miles from anything. Witch  country. Settled right there in the  Dead People Land where no one else  would, right on top of the old Anasazi  village. They're a dying clan. Just  the old ones now. All alone out there  in the middle of nothing. (drinks) They can keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do people really still believe in it  all? Ghosts, Sings, corpse sickness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends, I guess. Sometimes you go  along because it's a village thing,  or you don't want to disappoint  grandma. But sometimes, when you're  alone out there, far from town, and  the wind kicks up and sneaks into  your hogan... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John closes his eyes and drifts off. Thomas wanders into kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think John's out for the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday night in Chimney Rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a mug of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how does a person like you end up  teaching here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was younger I used to believe  that no matter how much you mucked  around in your life, one day, if you  listened hard enough, a voice would  tell you what you were really cut  out to do. And when it didn't show  up on schedule I decided to go look  for it. And I looked in a lot of  places, believe me. I drove that  road out there so far that the end  became the beginning again. And it  was when I got here that I realized  there never was going to be a voice.  So I stopped looking and took the  first job they offered me. That make  any sense to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know all about voices. Problem  is not all of them are very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you end up a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the evil of two lessers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you always this cryptic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. When you get to know me I can be  down right evasive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine pulls up to drop Thomas off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the lift. Tomorrow at  noon? At the little girl's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First trailer on the highway past  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say, Mr. Dagget, that you  don't seem very like a police officer  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what my bosses keep saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant it as a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So taken. Goodnight, Miss Henley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Tom-from-Los-Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas lying in his hotel bed, flinching through a dream- filled sleep. There's glimpses of shattered images: War. Death. And a s dark-haired girl. Thomas's eyes open and fix on the ceili Out his window, perched on the railing of his balcony, is something dark and winged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honey warmth of dawn heats the bluish, quiet streets The Town. Across shale hills and abandoned 19th century  miner's shacks, there echoes the faint, clear notes of a  trumpet. The bluesy notes drift over narrow dead-end stre junked cars, and the abandoned copper mine out past the e of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep in the tunneled rock, past the rusting conveyor belt Gabriel sits in a small cave blowing Miles Davis on his  trumpet. There's just the blanket he sits on and a single candle. Jerry comes around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get any sleep? (Jerry only stares) -- Just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Katherine climbs out of her pick-up she sees several o her students standing in a circle. Crouched in the center talking to them, is a man. Gabriel. Jerry stands nearby. Gabriel is showing a boy his trumpet. Demonstrating where put his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...There, and there. Now pucker your  lips... aim it that way, and just  blow a little bit, this is a special  trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy puffs lightly. The trumpet emits a piercing, clea note that SHATTERS a window high up in the abandoned part the building. The youngsters whoop and applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Timmy. Very good. Here,  have a Junior Mint on me. Open up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Timmy opens his mouth we clearly see Gabriel looking d into it. Looking for something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine approaches the scene warily. The children all b for their turn. Gabriel selects Sandra, one of Mary's sec grade friends, and puts her on his knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can barely get her fingers around the trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you see the man upstairs,  Sandra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who did, Sandra. Who talked to  the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where is Mary, Sandra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She isn't here. She's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got very pretty teeth, Sandra.  Here, let me see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gently pushes down her chin with his thumb, opens her  mouth, and gazes in. Katherine enters the circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think you're  doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel looks up, unperturbed, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just talking to the kids, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off his knee, Sandra. Everyone  else, go inside. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids reluctantly shuffle off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya, kids. Be sure to study your  math.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has the same sunglasses as Simon. The same cold, creep air about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry suddenly snorts loudly, trying to retrieve a sticky red glop that starts running out of his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone else does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what the hell is going  on, but you both better get out of  here. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs to his feet and stands close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You have no idea what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands there a beat. That terrible coldness that swirl about him. The shriek of ghosts under his breath. Then he climbs into the rambler with Jerry and pulls away. Kather watches the car drive off, then yells over to the school  janitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al! Keep an eye on the children for  me. I'll be right back. And call the  sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff? What the hell do I tell  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine gets into her pickup and starts the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine drives through the main drag and out past the f of town. As she passes the old copper mine she sees, park near the mine's tunnel entrance, Gabriel's rambler.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MARY'S GRANDMOTHER'S TRAILER
dialogues.text: As Katherine pulls up, she's surprised to see Thomas clim out of his own car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't suppose to be here till  noon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a little early yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to check on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes two of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the sandy lot that extends back from the trailer is a  wizened cottonwood tree. Katherine, Thomas, and Mary are  seated beneath its shade. Katherine is protective of the  little girl, running a hand maternally through her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you feeling, pumpkin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Dagget, Mary. He'd like  to ask you some questions. You don't  have to answer if you don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a dreamy, far-away look in Mary's eyes. It worrie Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, when you talked to man up in  the building --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Simon. What did Simon say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) That's funny. "Simon says".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Like the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good at it. I'm very clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to play together sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon even said so. He also asked if  I could keep a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something he gave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, pumpkin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it wouldn't be a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good friend not to tell,  Mary. But I'm a friend of Simon's  too. So if you ever want to tell,  you can to me. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a secret...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary lowers her head and shuts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But sometimes it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas and Katherine exchange looks. Mary's pretty eyes r again as she calmly asks, in that cute little eight year voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever killed a chinaman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Mary, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't bleed. Not the way you  and I do. Or maybe it was just the  cold...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas looks to Katherine for an explanation, but she's a confused as him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've killed them, you know. Lots.  You could always tell when they were  coming. There'd be the trumpets first.  Every note flat. Then those songs...  After that they'd charge. Right down  through the snow. The guns would  freeze and it would be just knives...  It was so cold and there were so  many of them. But I was smarter than  they were. Even at Chosin, I was  smarter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's been explaining this in a girlish, show-'n-tell ki of way. Suddenly her face cracks as her voice chokes with sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It scares me, Miss Henley. I hate  it. Please, make it stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She buries herself into Katherine's arms, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rocking her) It's okay... It's okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary suddenly pushes away and runs back toward the traile into the arms of her grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Miss Henley. We know  you love Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going to have the Enemy Ghost  Way. We leave this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandmother turns and walks back to the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will they do the ceremony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the home village. The Hand Trembler  must have found corpse sickness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're taking her away? Shouldn't  she see a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's already seen a doctor. (then, under her breath) That son of a bitch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel the children called him. The  little shit was hanging around my  kids this morning asking about Mary.  He and his buddy make a real pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's time I checked out Mr.  Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine turns from trailer and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where he parks his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine and Thomas drive back down the road leading to  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinamen? Chosin? I've never heard  her talk like that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chosin Reservoir was a Korean war  battle the Marines had against the  Chinese, supposedly the bloodiest  hand-to-hand fighting of the century.  Someone been teaching that to your  class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, right next to Jack 'N Jill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would she have heard it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody I can think of. (beat) Maybe one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Hawthorne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't like children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't and tell a story like  that to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls over to the side near the copper mine entrance. sign of the rambler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was there earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas drives up the dirt path to the mine's tunnel entra They climb out and stand near its mouth. In the dust is t rambler's tracks and several footprints leading into the  mine. Thomas steps up to the edge of the tunnel. It's a black,  yawning thing that swallows the sunlight whole for breakf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was smart I'd call the Sheriff  or somebody in town who knows this  place. Then again, there is one thing  worse than getting killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking like an idiot if it's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pops his trunk and takes out a flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, if someone has to fall a hundred  feet down a black pit, he should at  least be on official duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas switches on the light and takes a tentative step  inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then again, it is kind of spooky in  there. Here, you can hold the  flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun very quickly becomes a memory. And after the firs bend it isn't even that anymore. There's only the glow of the flashlight; glancing off the abrupt edges of tunneled rock. Here and there are the flotsam of a bankrupt indust dented ore carts lying on their side, rusted drill bits,  piles of support timbers. And all around them the sucking blackness of the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cold...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk further down into the mine. The atmosphere beco close and creepy. Thomas has been following tracks left i the dusty floor that abruptly disappear. He stops and sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A BAT suddenly SHRIEKS out of the darkness, glancing o Thomas's shoulder and TANGLING in Katherine's hair. She  screams and spins around, loosing her footing and half fa into a yawning ore chute she hadn't seen beside her. Thom rushes over and pulls her out. She climbs shakily to her  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas takes a last pass at the mine shaft with his  flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've seen enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns to leave the flashlight burns out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs it once against his thigh before he notices for first time a dim, amber light coming from a space between the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe a bum or  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But his gun's out at his side. Just in case. They follow light to the gap in the rock, gingerly stepping into

dialogues.speaker: A CAVERN
dialogues.text: -- That could easily belong to a bum. It's Gabriel and Je digs. Just the moldy blanket, single oil lamp, piles of  twinkie wrappers, And something else. From outside the cave it's the same whine, the same blurr that drips off Gabriel like sweat. But once they step int the room, into the lair, it suddenly jumps in volume. Thi is where Gabriel sleeps, and it's thicker here, like hone on the walls. Thomas has difficulty focusing his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Thomas can't hear Katherine anymore, her voice has  disappeared beneath the whine. As it becomes too much he  leans his weight against the rock wall and shuts his eyes It's then they come. Flashes of images: Of screams and fi Of impossible vistas of emptiness and death. And shriekin overhead, shrieking everywhere; grotesque, winged creatur with no eyes. Some with faces we know; Gabriel, Simon, an the gargoyle. All these images are being jammed into both their minds by the cave. Thomas forces his eyes open but the scenes playing all ar him won't go away. Tears are running down Katherine's fac as she stands there locked in the same images. Thomas stu about the room as if drunk, the visions, incomprehendibly black visions of war and destruction on an alien plateau, eat his brain. He sinks to his knees and begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no... Oh God no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine's curled up on the floor like a child, weeping. The images are driving them mad. Thomas, fighting the ins pounding at him, crawls pathetically across the floor to oil lamp. His fingers grasp it spasmotically as he rises his knees and leans back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HEAVES the lamp against the cave wall, where it EXPLOD the oil erupting into a swirling blaze that CONSUMES the  corner. The images break a second in the heat and light and sucki wind. Just long enough for Thomas to grab Katherine's arm and pull her out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine and Thomas lie in the dust outside the mine's t entrance. Catching their breath. Trying to organize and r the short circuits in their brains. Thomas rolls on his s squints at the sun. Katherine's voice is faint and raspy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... What was that? Hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No. The voices. They were screaming  and fighting over... theology. They  don't sweat much about that in hell.  But they do in... heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squeezes a handful of dirt in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The son of a bitch. He carries it  around with him like a photo album.  A big, greasy cloud wherever he goes.  They all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can that be heaven? Jesus Christ.  How? I don't even believe in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tears start rolling down her face. She looks up and s at the endless sky above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dumb fucking assholes! How could  you have done that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That extra chapter by St. John was  right. It's a war... Just like the  first one. Just like when the angel  Michael beat Lucifer and cast him  out. Only now they've turned on each  other... Turned on each other in a  civil war over theology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs hopelessly at the insanity of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweet God, theology. (sighs) "God's wild bunch". (shouts) God's morons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know know so much about  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just know. (shakes his head) Yes folks, the good news is that  there's life after death in heaven.  The bad news is that it's as screwed  up as here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were like us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are us. Aborted children. And  they need us. They need our corrupt,  dark souls for their fight. They  need...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine climbs abruptly to her feet and walks for the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what this is. I don't  know what I believe. I don't know if  my sanity is lying back in that cave  flopping around waiting for me. But  I know one thing. Those... Those  things aren't taking her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine and Thomas drive along in silence. Finally,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In those... visions... did you ever  see... God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine and Thomas open the trailer door and enter  cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas looks out the window and notices for the first tim parked behind the trailer, Gabriel's rambler. He immediat pulls out his pistol, runs for the closed door at the end the hall and KICKS it in. The door FLIES open, revealing  Gabriel sitting on the bed beside Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His gun's leveled at Gabriel's head. The angel sits there impassively, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know. Son of a bitch, the priest  wanna-be actually figured it out.  That's a rare club, son. At least  down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back away from the kid, man. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't feel anything, honest.  I'll have to tear her apart of course --  just the way it goes -- but it'll be  all right in the end. A good catholic  boy like you, Mr. Daggett, you should  be on my side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to watch that  profanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry suddenly LEAPS out from behind the door and TACKLES Thomas to the carpet. The gun skitters to one side as Jer SINKS his rotting teeth into Thomas's shoulder. Thomas cr out and SLAMS his fist against Jerry's head, knocking off ear. Gabriel turns back to Mary's frightened face and smiles a he runs a hand through her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll only be a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine suddenly HAMMERS Gabriel across the side of the head with a chair, KNOCKING him to the floor. As he gets she HITS him again. Thomas manages to bring his leg up and KICKS Jerry hard  against the chest, forcing him off. Gabriel GRABS both of Katherine's legs and PULLS, CRASHIN her flat on her back. Thomas scrambles for his gun, grabs it, and as Jerry come at him again spins and FIRES twice. The slugs RIP into Je chest and knock him to his knees. As the putrid, curdled  juices pump lumpily out of him, Jerry looks up at Thomas smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks man, I appreciate it. You're  a sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas FIRES a slug into his forehead. Jerry's brain wink out as he collapses to the floor, dead. Thomas's gun is abruptly WRENCHED from his hand onto the as Gabriel NAILS him with a thrown lamp, vaults the bed  between them, and grabs him by the collar, SLAMMING Thoma up against the wall. He looks down at Jerry's finally lif corpse, incensed at Thomas's handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little pest, do you have any  idea how hard it is to get one of  those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He THROWS Thomas down onto a table, SPLINTERING it. Kathe climbs shakily to her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch, why? Why do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm an angel, you miserable  wretch! I kill first borns while  their mothers watch! I turn whole  cities into salt! I even, when I  feel like it, rip the souls from  little girls! And from now until  eternity, the only thing you'll be  able to count on in your pathetic  little existence is never knowing  why! (deep breath) I'm wasting my time here. (turns to Mary) C'mon petunia, let's get on with  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel walks over to the bed. The moment he gets close,  Mary lifts Thomas's pistol up from the sheets and SHOOTS twice, the impact KNOCKING him on his ass. Katherine rushes to Mary, scoops her up and runs for the  door. She pauses beside Thomas, still lying in the wrecka of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine disappears through the bedroom doorway. Gabriel spins around and stands. Thomas leaps from a ragg crouch, HITTING Gabriel low with a body-block. It's like butting concrete. Gabriel picks up Thomas by the scruff of the neck and HEA him THROUGH the flimsy room paneling. Thomas CRASHES with mass of splinters into the kitchen. He stumbles backward  hopelessly as Gabriel peruses him through the trailer. He desperately throws pots, glasses, anything at Gabriel. Fi trapped, he scrambles up onto the dinner table, SCATTERIN salt and sugar bowls, and DIVES through the levored windo

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Thomas, in a hail of shattered glass, smacks the red eart pulls himself up to his knees and tries to stumble and cr away as Gabriel BANGS open the trailer door and stomps do the stairs toward Katherine, her arms around Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eases his gait, measuring the distance to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just those sunglasses coming. Those endless pits black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Have Her!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine lifts Thomas's pistol and FIRES. Again. Again. slugs BANG off the corregated metal, SMASH a window, KICK some dust, And PUNCTURE the propane tank beneath the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: -- WUMPP-BAM
dialogues.text: The entire trailer EXPLODES in a fiery cloud of TWISTING  METAL. Katherine huddles Mary close to the ground as flaming chu WHACK everywhere. Gabriel is HAMMERED to the earth and disappears in the ro fire cloud. Thomas, further away, is KNOCKED head-over-he in the ruddy dust. The fire cloud dissipates quickly into the sky, leaving b scorched brush, and little else, crackling softly. Gabrie body looks blackened and still. Katherine rushes to Thoma who's pulled himself up to his knees, a ragged slice abov his eye bleeding badly. She helps him to his feet and ove to the pickup, where he sits down against the tire as  Katherine pulls out her first aid kit. Mary's there, stan with her shaken grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re grandmother) Where...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was coming up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Gabriel dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's knelt down beside Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not like you and me. You've  got to cut their hearts out. The  only thing God gave them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheriff car ROARS up, the two deputies exiting warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine's wiping the blood out of Thomas's eye. Gasping from the shearing pain, he tosses an ID at the foot of th deputy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAPD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at it, hands  it to partner) That's a start. How about the rest  of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From somewhere back in town there's the growl of a volunt fire engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man over there. He's wanted.  Murder. I'm taking him in. (grimaces) -- Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pain's unbareable. Katherine dabs his cut with  disinfectant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're going to the hospital  first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- No, I have to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the pain. The second deputy has walked over to Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuff him. We'll take him to the  hospital in our car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- No, you don't understand. You  have to let me have him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The volunteer fire engine growls up through the weeds,  drowning out Thomas's words. Two firemen kneel down besid him with medical kits. The deputy has walked over to his partner and the two are dragging back between them a cuffed, comatose Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarse, faint) You'll never hold him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas tries to get up, but the pain and a hand from the  firemen keep him down. As the deputies pass, he manages t desperately grab the one's pant cuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take off his sunglasses... Jesus  Christ, just take off his  sunglasses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel's head lies low between the shoulders. The deputy looks with concern at the firemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re Thomas) He'll be all right. Just a bad hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deputy nods. As they carry on to the car with Gabriel the angel turns his head slightly and smiles a smile only for Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to partner) Let's get a splint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patrol car pulls away. As the firemen walk back to th engine, Thomas looks frantically at Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want Mary to stay alive past  sundown we have to leave, and we  have to do it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lock eyes. Then Katherine without a word helps Thoma up into the passenger side of the pickup. Mary gathers he grandmother into the pickup's bed and climbs up beside he as Katherine starts the engine. The firemen turn in confu as the truck peels out of the lot and up onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine's truck shoots by. Just before town, near the c mine, it slows down at a junction. And there, lying on its side down the embankment, is the  sheriff's patrol car. A single, bent tire turns aimlessly Katherine hits the gas and takes the junction that leads  away from town, out onto the endless expanse of the plate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bandage on Thomas's forehead covers most of one eye. closes the other tightly, riding a spasm of pain, before  letting his forehead rest against the door glass and gazi out at the empty tracks of land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine looks over her shoulder to Mary's grandmother  sitting in the truck bed. She nods in understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine's pickup passing alone through the wrinkled des

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trading post with a few pumps, growing orange in the  weakening afternoon light. A scruffy dog barks constantly the teenage Indian sticks the nozzle in Katherine's picku Still glassy-eyed with throbbing pain, Thomas takes anoth handful of aspirin and climbs out of the cab. There's a tiny, weatherbeaten church across the weedy lot from the trading post with a pay phone bolted to it. Thom crunches across the lot, picks up the receiver, and punch in some numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: County Coroner's office, Assistant  Coroner Raphael speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't crazy, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Thomas hangs up. He backs away from the phone and for the first time notices the church it's attached to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas steps inside. It's empty and there's some doubt wh it's been used in a generation. The pews are dusty and  scraped, some broken down completely. Thomas sits in one looks across the space and dust and years to the crucifix hanging behind the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the deal, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pew creaks and groans as he shifts his weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, do you have any kind of plan  here? Cause I'm just about of ideas,  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus' pressed-metal eyes gaze only upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even listen? Do you still  come to places like this? Old Man,  you have been calling me most of my  goddamn life, but every time I get  close, you just keep moving that far  away. What's it to be? You want me  to kill your henchmen? Can't you  even control your own killers anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas holds his face in his hands a silent moment. When raises we see the raw hurt in the eyes as he shouts,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only reply is dust dancing in the light and the rumbl of semis on the highway. Standing in the back, watching Thomas with tears welling her eyes, is Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road's turned to dirt and the plateau into a maze of  ragged cliffs and brutally hacked canyons. The light is shadowy and golden now as Katherine's pickup turns off the small dirt road onto an even smaller one th winds impossibly up the side of a volcanic butte. Higher and higher the truck climbs on the rutted and  treacherous path, till at last it crests the ridge and co upon

dialogues.speaker: THE VILLAGE
dialogues.text: Perched frighteningly on the leading edge of Old Woman Bu this is the home of the Bitter Sky Clan. The village is a small grouping of ancient adobe walled hogans first built thousand years ago by the Anasazi. There's no electricity here, no TV antennas or frozen yogurt. Just the slow curl cooking fires drifting up through smoke holes and the ste deeply lined face of an old Navaho man approaching the pi as Katherine stops. The old man wears jeans, a bright maroon silk shirt, and black felt reservation hat with a turkey feather. He hold in his right hand a small leather case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Bartholomew Grey Horse, born to  the Deer Spring Clan, born for the  Slow Talking People. Today I am the  yataalii for Mary Tsosie of the Bitter  Sky Clan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man, Bartholomew Grey Horse, walks up to Mary and her grandmother sitting in the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya-tah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya-tah-hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several villagers approach and greet Mary and her grandmo some nodding politely to Thomas and Katherine as they cli out of the cab. Nearly all of them are elderly. Thomas, one eye still half-shut by a bandage, walks over the village's edge where a short stone wall, and little e separates the adobe homes from the long, 2000 foot drop t the desert floor. He leans against it and gazes out on a  view that must encompass half the world. In all direction for tens upon tens of miles, there are only volcanic spir and crumbling buttes, all reduced from up here to short,  ominous playthings. A village truly alone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a good place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's appeared beside him. Thomas crouches down to her le and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's sight is on the view, eyeing it critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Separate water source. Stocked grain.  Only one possible approach. A man  could, with the proper defenses,  hold off an entire battalion for  weeks. Months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas's voice sighs sadly as he runs a hand softly throu her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of you is that talking,  Mary? Or do you even know anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's eyes fill with tears as her grandmother appears an leads her back to the adobe hogans. Grey Horse, the yataalii, is there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will start the Sing soon to remove  the Yei spirit and stop the ghost  sickness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This might not be the work of a Navaho  ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night creeps over the Chuska Mountains across the crusty  caliche flats and over the village, pushing back the dyin day to a thin, fading blue line etched across the horizon As the darkness settles on the hogans we see a glimmer of light from within and the rising, guttural chants of the  yataalii.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the village, beneath the surface of the butte, is t large communal kiva room. Accessible by a single ladder  through a single smoke hole, it is down here that the vil performs its Enemy Ghost Way for Mary. The little girl is there, attended by her grandmother, si stoically still on a blanket as Grey Horse, grasping his  painted prayer sticks, by the glow of a fire chants the E Ghost Way cure. Katherine's eyes sting in the smokey air she watches Grey Horse take from his case small handfulls colored sand that he pours in fine patterns onto the floo The whole Bitter Sky Clan surrounds them. Old, lined face A small, dying people here to support its last granddaugh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine stands there in the chilly darkness outside the kiva. Mary's grandmother, passing with some other women,  pauses and squeezes Katherine's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we sleep, Katherine. Tomorrow,  after dark, we begin again.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE KIVA
dialogues.text: The fire has died to embers, casting its weak glow on a n empty room.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Katherine wanders along the edge of the village, turning her collar under a blinding mass of stars. There's nothin beyond the village. Not a light, not a sound. Say the win It is the icy brush of wind on her body that now whispers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the wind, it is low and thin and hoarse. Like the wi it seems to come from everywhere. And, like the wind, it utterly without pity or remorse. Katherine turns. Perched on the wall behind her in a low crouch is a figur clad entirely in layers of black. Its head and hands are  hairless and waxy white. There are eyes in this winged he but blood chilling ones of putrid yellow. There are endle scars and shapes and wrinkles, but mostly, only, there ar the eyes. Katherine gulps down, with only partial success, the hyst rising in her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, I can't do this. I can't do  this anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must talk, Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's takes all her strength to look upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're... You're... (tries to form the  word) ...God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God is love, Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes narrow. Rippling pools of unfathomable evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I don't love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a crouched silhouette beside the figure. Dimmer.  Skinny. A wheezing sycophant. An afterthought. Katherine backs away from both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I can't do this tonight. Go  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can kill you, Katherine. I can lay  you out and fill your mouth with  your mother's feces. Or I can talk  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine stops. Faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am here, before you, in a form to  put you at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sycophant shivers and ruffles something feathery unde its cloak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rarely do this in person. I am,  perhaps, somewhat out of touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you one of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not an angel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am an angel. A very special  one. The first. The oldest. The naive  eagle scout, he once loved me above  all others, and I him. It was the  only true love for either of us, but  like all true love, it couldn't  possibly last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure cranes his neck around to the horizon beyond t The movement makes a liquid, snapping sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winged party boys will come,  Katherine. They'll come to feed on  the guts of your little Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my interests...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The naive eagle scout, he has his  interests too. He even has a place  for them, as I do for mine. Big,  shiny place. You'd like it. Only  it's been empty for a long time.  Can't open till after the  resurrection. The problem's with the  hired help. Always had problems with  the hired help. They're arrogant,  boastful little pricks. Not like me.  What I did I did for love. But they,  the winged party boys, even before  the park could open for its first  customer, they started fighting over  the popcorn stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure shifts his perch on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Katherine, heaven can't  start accepting guests till this  fight is settled. And without people,  there is no heaven. All those good  and true souls left mouldering in  the ground clutching their H-tickets  and waiting and waiting and waiting...  Some, lying down there with the worms  century after century, they start to  get doubts about the whole program.  That's when, out of sheer boredom,  some of them come to me. Because I'm  always open for business. 24 hours a  day, seven days a week. Even on  Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure's face darkens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the angels cheat. They sneak  a few souls in to help with the fight.  The really dark ones. And now one of  them has found a special soul so  wonderfully sick that it might just  win it for them. And if one side  wins, even the wrong one, then there's  no fight. And if there's no fight,  there can be a heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if there's a heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be very unhappy. (beat) I am here to help you and the little  bitch not because I love you, not  because I care about you, but because  I want this war to go on and on and  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure straightens up, stretching its spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bring you the chance to save your  Mary, Katherine. And along the way,  stop the resurrection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen when I speak. Now go to bed,  Katherine. Tomorrow, I promise you,  is a big day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas's sitting on the hard-packed floor, leaning agains the adobe wall, maybe trying to sleep. Mostly trying to i the thumping pain in his head. The oil lamp's flame shudd in the gust of Katherine opening the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now. They start again tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at the end of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Enemy Way chant removes the  invading yei ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it work on a general's soul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see. (beat) How's the head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still attached. Barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down on the floor beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, I'll change the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She carefully unwraps the blood-soaked gauze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I must be doing it wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She peels back the compress and dabs the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the devil tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How nice. Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main one. Satan. Lucifer. The  dark angel. You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he have to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That he did it all for love. That  and I have a choice. Mary's life or  a billion souls waiting in the  pipeline for heavenland to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not kidding, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satan? You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas suddenly slams his fist against the wall in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wasn't I!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can double date next time if it's  that important to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand, I've spent my  whole life... (looks upward) I don't suppose it would occur to  anyone in authority to fill me in on  what's going on every once in awhile,  huh? Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ache in his head's flared up. He leans it back agains the wall to ease the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything about the Nicene  Council? About the rank of Jesus  Christ in the holy Trinity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't seem important to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine finishes taping the new bandage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a priest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A near miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This may be your last chance to tell  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wind outside rustles through the hogans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other night, you were talking  about waiting for a voice to call  you to something. Well, let me tell  you, the worst thing that can happen  to you is to be called to something.  Since I can remember a voice from  somewhere deep in the Church called  me. So loud and so often that by  thirteen I knew I was going to be a  priest. You know what that's like?  My parents, friends, all of them  thought I was crazy. But see, I had  this voice. The voice that kept  coaxing me along, telling me there  was a reason. So I entered the  seminary and was half way to my  starched white collar when my mother,  father, and my little brother were  wiped out in a car crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, the old emotions creeping back up on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had never asked anything of the  voice. Not when the neighborhood  kids made fun of me, not when my  father looked down at me like some  knock-kneed faggot. I never questioned  a damn thing. But on the morning I  spent looking down at three parallel  graves, I asked it one question.  Why. Why were these people taken  from me? And the voice, that same  voice that would wrench me out of my  sleep some nights with its jabbering,  it was suddenly stone silent. It was  the only question I ever asked of it  and it just left me hanging in the  fucking wind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He blinks back the tears welling in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So after that I traded in priest  school for homicide school. Because  if God wouldn't talk to me the devil  sure as hell would, and his ways  were a lot easier to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've never seen God, have we? Not  in any of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, He's certainly a shy son of a  bitch, I'll give Him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we're not supposed to. Maybe  that's faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still have faith in anything,  Katherine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have faith in Mary. And that I'm  going to save that little girl from  those creeping things out there.  From all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you were called to something  after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we both were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The oil lamp wanes and fades. Katherine lays her head on  Thomas's shoulder, and as darkness swallows them he holds her. They hold each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John the bus driver lying fully dressed on his bed asleep The night breeze through the window, and maybe something  else, tickles his nose. His eyes open, blink, turn left,  right, then up, -- And see Gabriel perched on the headboard, staring down him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy sleeper, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's eyes open wide in shock. Gabriel's skin is blacken and blistered in parts. Whole shards of his shirt are mis John tries to sit up but Gabriel forces his head back dow with his palm. With the ease of a spider he slides down a beside John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't -- Don't hurt me, man. My  wallet's in the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be such a materialist, John. (sees empty bourbon  bottle on dresser,  sighs) No end to your bad habits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to have that nose looked  at, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel leans said nose in very close and whispers,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they, John? Katherine and  Mary? Where would they go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Mary? I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do. Think hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really. I don't know. The school  maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're not even trying, John.  You're Katherine's best friend. She  tells you everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just the driver, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel extends a blistered, open palm over John's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can help you remember, John...

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: We see Gabriel leaning over John as a sickly yellow glow  begins to rise and reflect off the walls. Beneath it come John's worst and deepest screams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel SPLASHING the soot off his face and arms in a sma institutional bathroom. He looks at himself in the mirror runs a hand through his hair, and walks out the door into

dialogues.speaker: A HOSPITAL CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: At the end of it is the intensive care unit, that  institutional purgatory where a small handful of patients wired and tubed and oxygenated, lay inconclusively betwee life and death. There's a nurse's station there, all heal status video screens and a single nurse that looks up fro her work at Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's going to die here soon.  I'll just be a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no visitors allowed in ICU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The timing's important. I can smell  these things, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse reaches for the telephone. Gabriel takes it awa from her with one hand and with the other grasps her face open-palmed and whispers,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse slides out of her chair and collapses to the fl Gabriel pulls out the metal clipboards holding each patie chart and flips through them, tossing one after another a as unsuitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recovering... Recovering... Stable... (finally settles on  one) Deteriorating critical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfied, he steps over to one of the beds, pulls back t curtain and sits down beside an unconscious, middle-aged  woman. He watches patiently, listening the beeping scrawl the EKG above her. It was weak to begin with but now it's faltering badly,  becoming the unsynched etchings of a child. A beeping ala has begun to ring and her breathing is slowing to nothing At the last possible moment Gabriel places his fingers ac her face, whispering to her, coaxing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, not just yet. Come on back.  That's it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EKG's still flat but the woman is breathing. She begi to choke, to cough, then suddenly sits up and opens her e She looks in disbelief around her, finally settling on  Gabriel's grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of utter desolation and sadness sweeps over her as she begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon, don't start... (looks at chart) -- Rachael. Here... (hands her kleenex) It's only for a short time. (grins) Promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun cresting the Lukachukais and warming with honey  colored reflection the interior of the hogan. Katherine's head is still on Thomas's shoulder, the two o them asleep sitting against the wall. Katherine opens her eyes and rises stiffly. She looks out the simple window to the glow of morning without expressi turns, and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE OTHER HOGAN
dialogues.text: Mary's Grandmother and some of the other elderly villager are attending Mary as Katherine enters. Mary is sitting u in her bed. She smiles at Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Miss Henley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, pumpkin. Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey Horse is kneeling near the bed preparing a bowl drin Into it he crushes charcoal, dodge weed, juniper and ghos plant. This he stirs, heats over flame, and feeds to Mary She grimaces and leans back in the bed as Grey Horse says brief prayer.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Katherine runs into Thomas outside the hogan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shitty. Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She accepts a mug, blowing a cloud of steam off the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do if he comes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean when, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no phone here? Radio? (she just looks at  him) Stupid question. (beat) If we were smart we'd leave. Get to  a town. A sheriff station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's ceremony isn't over yet. The  Enemy Ghost Way. The alien spirit  hasn't been driven out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really believe in the ceremony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have believed in any of  this three days ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) So we stay and dump the General's  soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With one shot left. The spares -- (sniffs his shirt) -- And a change of clothing, are all  still at the hotel. (sighs) We're going to have to come up with  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could always ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas looks up. She's referring to Lucifer, who's appear perched on the edge of the low, eye-level hogan roof. The sycophant is also nearby, chattering its teeth and starin at Katherine with jealous, rabid eyes. Lucifer shivers, a claw turning up the collar of his cloa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always forget how cold it gets in  the desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swimming, bottomless eyes fall on Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Daggett, I presume. How's the  faith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas can't bring himself to say anything. To form the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come come, must you be so wishy-washy  about everything? With the absent- minded eagle scout, I can see that.  But you're looking at the devil man,  say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better. Can I have some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas gingerly hands him the cup. The angel Lucifer lift it, and with something unimaginably awful darting out of mouth, drinks. He offers the mug back to Thomas for a sip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes it. Cranes his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
